comments.commentBody: My NY Jewish partner calls this Episcopalian a "Jewophile." What that means is that I love Jewish moral seriousness and humanism, and the great leadership most Jews have given to all progressive causes since they got to America. But I bow to no one in my opposition to Likud, AIPAC, and the Shel Adelson-style rich American right-wing Jewish hyper-Zionists and neocon war-mongers who lied us into Iraq to "protect" Israel (and weakened Israel radically in the event) and who now want to shove America into another proxy war to "protect" Israel in Iran. Having grown up a young white liberal in MLK's Atlanta, I especially admire any people who oppose "their own people" when "their own people" are oppressing others. So three cheers for all the majority of American Jews like Robert Bernstein, Don Goldstein above who stand, like the Israelis of B'eth Selem, in solidarity with the Palestinians and oppose their oppression by some of "their own people." I hope that other mainline American Christian churches will follow the lead of the Presbyterians, which I fervently applaud. The more wake-up calls we can give Likud and its rabid American backers, the better for Israel, not to mention the Palestinians. Israel's treatment of the Palestinians and stone-walling on a two-state solution can not end well for Israeli Jews, especially in a Middle East that all of America's power is quite literally as helpless to control for Israel as it was to win a permanent "victory" in Iraq or Afghanistan.
Tell that to the UN, which provides better free health insurance coverage for all Palestinian refugees, including those that commit terrorist acts, than here in the US.

The Israelis kidnap THOUSANDS of Palestinians living on their own land and imprison them for DECADES, often without charge.

Three teenagers are captured on land that does not belong to them and suddenly it's the second shoah?

Grotesque.

The second intifada has long sense ended. In those years of relative quiet, when did we hear the Israeli government's willingness to stop settlement comstruction and work towards a peace? The Palestineans did just thay, and still nothing. The Israelis have only stalled in order to change the facts on the ground in their favor. Hypocrites and liars, the right wing lot of them.

I recognize that people of faith feel it important to live that faith.
I am disappointed to see that here it takes the form of pressuring one side but not the other.
How about divesting from Palestinian causes until they stop shooting missiles into cities and kidnapping teenagers?
"But we know from scripture that the meek will inherit the earth." Still waiting for that platitude to become a tangible reality.
You mean meek like Hamas? Or Hezbollah?
Always? How about David against the mighty goliath, a Palestinian, I believe.
I agree with the Presbyterians. The Israelis have always felt that might makes right. But we know from scripture that the meek will inherit the earth.
Most in Congress are interested solely in the flow of money from Israeli supporters. That flow is heaviest to those Congressmen willing to follow the donors'  dictates.

Of course, Israeli injustice and cruelty. Those meek, non-violent Palestinians who never lifted a hand to throw a rock or who suffer always turning the other cheek. Hardly a thought of retaking the Land ever crosses their minds, those poor suffering souls who did nothing to bring this on themselves, but run away to let the amassed Arab armies destroy Israel In 1948 and afterwards and who dream that day will one day come.

The Israeli lobby tried hard but failed to muzzle the Presbyterians. Hopefully more American organizations (especially Congress) will learn from this experience and take a stand against Israeli injustice and cruelty.

Distributed Computing is not a branch of computer science. It's best described as a computer architecture where the computing power or capacity is spread out (distributed) among many nodes, or "scaled out". This is an alternative to concentrating the computing power into one node, or "scaled up".
That aside, the article was really quite good!

Impact investing in peace would have been a better path, see this week's Forward - Presbyterians: Choose Impact Investing Over BDS http://blogs.forward.com/forward-thinking/200184/presbyterians-choose-im...
Fontaine scored 13 goals in ONE world cup , Muller scored 14 in TWO world cups. Fontaine still owns the record in one world cup .

I think that Gerd Muller "only" :-) scored 10 goals in 1970, So Just Fontaine is still the record holder.
That being said, Muller's performance was probably more impressive since that, compared to Fontaine, he played in an era where scoring what much much rarer.

Benzema very reasonably could be on six goals-challenging fellow Frenchman Just Fontaine, who scored all his 13 goals in six games of a single World Cup, 1958, which was the lifetime record until he was passed by Gerd Muller in 1974, but he lost one when the second goal v Honduras was ruled an own goal, he missed the penalty, and the ref waved off the last kick.
Clarey, like several other Times writers, has referred to the Swiss conceding only six goals in 10 qualifiers. As I said to the other, Lawrie Mifflin, who blogged this match, Switzerland's group was almost preternaturally easy. The ten matches were against Slovenia, Norway, Iceland, Albania and Cyprus. you could make a very convincing argument that the Swiss defense isn't all that good based on conceding six to that motley assortment of opponents.
Like England, Switzerland was undone by the triple threat to themselves of mediocre center halves (Senderos and Djourou are below that level, as any Arsenal fan can attest), fullbacks who are a real threat going forward, and not supportive enough of the center halves coming back, and central midfielders who provided insufficient cover.
France can perhaps be forgiven for some carelessness after going up 5-0. The Xhaka goal was possible not because of defect in the center of defense, but because right back Mathieu Debuchy played him onside, all the other defenders having pulled up. I'm actually surprised at Deschamps' choices on the back line, but they've worked.

Without seeing exactly what happened in the play, you don't know who was at fault. It easily could have been Pereira's fault - if he tried for a sliding tackle during the opponent's kick. In that case, he would have been the player who committed the foul. I'm not saying that is what happened as I didn't see the game, just that because he got kneed in the head does not mean he was fouled by the other player.

Well, I did watch the game.  The knee to Pereira's head was not intentional and was the regrettable result of a collision that was neither player's fault.  It happens.  No one deserved to be disciplined.  That being said, anytime a player sustains that type of blow to the head they should not be allowed back into match or to play again until they have received the full battery of test and results necessary to ensure that they fit to play.

Not a red-card offense. It was unintentional, indeed, initially looked like Pereira could have been carded for the way he came in. After replay, it was clear what had happened. The English player could not have stopped the way he fell over when Pereira came in. Not dangerous play on the English side. No card needed. It was a good call by the ref.

Looked like he got kneed in the temple or close to it - easily could've quickly died from that. Should have been taken out of the game, and the player who so dangerously kneed him should've been red-carded or worse.
Because it was clearly an accident.

Well, you have to understand that most soccer players writhing on the ground are faking it, trying to get a penalty kick, free kick, yellow/red card for the opponent, etc.  This kind of behavior is punishable by fine in the NBA, but in soccer it's considered part of the game, even an admirable tactic.

Yes, someone has to buy, but this lowers the value of the stock price.  If large investors dump a lot of shares, the value drops as there are more sellers than buyers.  The news of this will also prompt others to sell their shares, either for business reasons (higher risk of falling prices) or for solidarity of the cause.
And what happens when every moral person divests?

If one holder of stock in a company sells, someone else has to buy.

You can "divest" but as far as the market is concerned, that is just a stock sale from one party to another.

Obviously, somebody on the other side of the deal thinks differently from the divesting owner.

That makes for "news", but has little effect on the company whose stock you sell, and probably *zero* effect on their business practices unless you are a major stockholder (which is rarely the case in publicly traded stocks).

The fraction of the total stock of these companies (Caterpillar 68.28B, Hewlett-Packard 64.04B and Motorola Solutions 17.12B) that the Presbyterians own is $21 million out of of a market cap of roughly 149.44 Billion or a 0.0001 fraction or 1 one-hundreth of 1 percent.

I'm sure that is going to shake up the market on Monday.

(If you believe that, I have a bridge over the East River in NY to sell cheap.)

It what Americans want.  They are tired of politicians ignoring them.  The pretend bickering between Republicans and Democrats was just a distraction while they both ignored our laws and the wishes of the American people.
As the article mentions many Jews support this action by the Presbyterians. In Israel itself many many Jews are opposed to the settlements.
How many?
This will be seen as just another example of Christian criticism of Jews, as as such will backfire.

Untrue--the Security Counsel routinely vetoes resolutions declaring East Jerusalem 'occupied territory.' Get Facts straight.

But as long as we're on the subject, I request you provide me with an example of Arab concessions--let's not go back to the cleansing of Jewish neighborhoods in Jerusalem under the Grand Mufti (who met with you-know-who to request a final solution be implemented in the holy land and take care of the problem). Please give me an example of concessions the Arabs have made since, say, 1973. There's the official recognition of Israel's right to exist in 1988--wow, I'm impressed--but that's a bit dodgy since their own media and politicians continue to demand the complete obliteration of Israel. But nevermind all that. What are these Palestinian concessions you speak of, sir or madam? Thank you for your time.

When you can show proof that Jordan or Egypt illegally occupied anything you get a cookie. Till then you can keep making things up in your mind till you are blue in the face and it still wont be true. Find one resolution condemning Jordan or Egypt for an "illegal occupation" Just one. You wont find it because not only was the occupation agreed to by the Palestinians it was also agreed to by Israel.  You cant have an illegal occupation when the occupied agree to it. Currently the Palestinians do not agree to your brutal and racist occupation.

East Jerusalem is currently being ethnically cleansed of Palestinians in favor of Jewish immigrants—just read about Silwan. Yet the article author (or whoever you seem to be addressing) is propositioned to comment on a hypothetical future scenario? Such is the tragic logic of those fighting the realization of universal human rights in the Holy Land.

The Presbyterian Church has certainly not voted itself 'on the right side of history' on an extremely complex issues that involves Arabs in Gaza and the Jordan Valley firing rockets not at military targets, but civilian Israeli population centers, a flagrantly illegal act according to any and all conventions of war (Geneva), which detail is nearly never mentioned, nor is the fact that Arabs have 22 sovereign nations of their own which contain numerous repressed minorities.

As a matter of policy, the issue of settlement in the West Bank is very different from the question of the sovereignty of Jerusalem which, notwithstanding three offers from sitting Israeli leaders offering the Arabs sovereignty over portions of the city, has been, since census records were kept, a majority Israelite city. West bank settlements should and must stop, with adequate safeguards for Hebrew religious sites. Jerusalem should be an international city in some sense, ideally, as the last pope suggested, but has also been the cultural seat of the Jews for 3200 years, notwithstanding relatively brief periods of expulsion by Romans (70 CE and 135 when, if memory serves, the city was burnt and the 2nd temple destroyed, all not to mention the brutal Hellenic conquest slightly earlier).
Thank god. Maybe others will follow this example, and pressure Israel to stop building settlements on the future state of the Palestinians. The Palestinians need a home too.

If it is complete meaningless, why were groups strongly trying to convince them to not vote for the divestment?  Why was there quick reactions of outrage?  This is a divestment of 3 businesses, not political or charity organizations, so why were lobbyists and rabbis getting involved?
Perhaps it is not completely meaningless, but it is only meaningful in making the situation worse.
WWII

A completely meaningless gesture (the article says they own $21 mm in stock in companies with a combined market cap of many tens of billions). And doubly ironic that this happens shortly after Abbas invites Hamas into his government (but hey, that is not an "obstacle to peace", only "settlements" are "obstacles to peace")
All it will do is send another signal to the Palestinians that they don't have to compromise in negotiations and make any hard choices because some do-gooder ignorant liberals in the West will somehow pressure Israel to give them what they want without any negotiations; and it will also further convince a slice of Israeli Jews that the world is so biased against them that they would be idiotic to take any risks for peace.
A lot of people want a better life.  That doesn't give them the right to break the law.  Who do you think pays to feed, clothe, and house poor immigrants?
Umm, I dunno. Maybe because they feel they should act like Christians and act upon their concern for the oppressed.

Yes, that could be it. Or perhaps it could be anti-Semitism.

There are many clear cut cases of human rights violations around the world occurring every day which an organization fighting human rights abuses might choose as its focus. The Israeli Palestine situation is, on the other hand, complex and arises from a long series of events. It lends itself nicely to prolonged analysis and personal judgements for or against one side or the other and for dramatic attention-grabbing announcements of the conclusions reached. It is a perfect debate in which to engage for people who simply dislike Jews or Palestinians, because it provides the opportunity to make find fault with cover for the true motivation. Like the protestants and the catholics in Northern Ireland, each side is always wiling to analyze any situation in which the other has been involved and find fault, and sometimes there is fault, but the bottom line is that they just don't like each other. Because of this participants in the debate must expect to be screened for their bona fides, similar to the screening that might be done with child care workers to exclude the pedophiles.

So in this case we have 613 Presbyterians voting of whom 310 we know nothing about vote to divest three investments, and 303 vote not to do that, and it makes the front page of the NYT.

What a farce.
In the US theists don't lose their civil rights because of their beliefs, including make statements about political issues.
Why does the Presbyterian church need to involve themselves in something like this? This is clearly a political statement they shouldn't be making.
Are human rights not important priorities to have for a Christian organization? Seems that's what the New Testament was mostly about as I recall.

These churches face many important internal issues, and externally, there are human rights issues, many more pressing than this, around the world. Of the thousands of other more worthwhile activities possible, why pick Israel Palestine as a central focus of the activities of the church?

I never heard what I considered to be a good answer to that question when I asked it in relation to the United Church of. Canada.

Interesting story. The United Church of Canada also has been pre-occupied with gay rights and Israeli/Palestinian issues over the last decade or so, and it has  been losing members and influence over this period too.  Shouldn't these organizations have other priorities?

The article indicates that he has transformed the lives of elderly, frail residents, that he has implemented the values of his Ashanti culture--to revere one's elders. Yet he is still criticized. It's obvious why. Clearly, our  American culture needs more people like Mr. Addo if only to supplant the narrow-minded, always negative American attitude. Thank goodness more and more Ghanaians are  immigrating to America.
Only if they WANT their pics posted
Check out the slideshow!
He should also post photos of his clients working out.
I can see now why the Presbyterian Church (SA) is losing membership. With all the critical world and domestic issues, it decides to devote heated debate on a feel good,  meaningless measure.
Paula, the church made a political statement, this is not even a question.

That offer to broker a meeting between Netanyahu and the Church's leaders on the condition the divestment measure goes has got to be the most boneheaded negotiating/lobbying move I have ever seen.  Who in their right mind dictates that the other side folds just for the right to come to the table when they are the ones trying to get the other party to see things their way.  If this is how they negotiate, is it any wonder why there hasn't been any semblance of a settlement for more than 50 years?  Pure blindness and arrogance

And across Canada voters are preparing to give the boot to the neocon Harperites despite a four-way split in the "progressive" vote. In Ontario scarcely 30 per cent of voters went for the lie that deficits are an existential threat and austerity is prosperity. In Quebec the Harperites are a distant fourth in popularity.
(Under Harper, what used to be known as the Government of Canada is now called The Harper Government. Think of Ted Cruz ideology in a bland personality that despite its lack of colour bizarrely celebrates militarism and is second only to the U.S. in its enthusiasm for Israeli annexationists.)
Alberta, the only Republican province in Canada is now Harper's only stronghold. Every time you see mention of Canada supporting tar sands and the Keystone pipeline, all it means is that hard-right oil biz reactionaries want to get rich. Canadians are opposed to the environmental disaster of tar sands exploitation.
Correction: To the left side of history.
